quotes.snippets: The CRISPR-Cas9 system appeared as a "Swiss army knife" (Mans et al., 2015) in the researcher's molecular toolbox because it allowed the performance of several genetic modifications in a fast and efficient way. Furthermore, the requirement of a constant selective pressure during fermentation is negated since CRISPR-Cas9 allows a markerless genetic manipulation. In addition, several design-build-test cycles are always necessary, which increases the number of modifications required [6](Rodrigues et al., 2017). By using CRISPR-Cas9 systems, genetic editing has become multiplex possible, which may significantly decrease the time to perform the designed genetic modifications for a cell factory construction. The flexibility of CRISPR-Cas9 allied with the researcher's inventiveness resulted in the development of systems that facilitate and accelerate metabolic engineering processes. Researchers are not only focused on developing new CRISPR-based strategies for direct genome engineering but also on applying CRISPR-Cas9 to improve other conventional molecular biology lab practices, speeding up the strain building process. For example, Li et al. (Li et al., 2019) developed a CRISPR system capable of sequential rounds of gene targeting with simultaneous gRNA plasmid curing mediated by CRISPR-Cas9. Moreover, in Zhang et al.'s work (Zhang et al., 2019), the developed CRISPR method skips the Escherichia coli transformation and verification steps.

quotes.snippets: Advanced technologies such as clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas9 is being used to accelerate genetic engineering of microbes as it permits rapid and efficient editing of the genome by replacing 20-nucleotide sequences of a chimeric single-guide RNA (sgRNA) complementary to the target sequence of interest (Cho et al., 2018). Immediately, the Cas9-sgRNA complex binds to the target DNA sequence, the endonuclease activity of the CRISPR-associated protein (Cas9 protein) cleaves the DNA (Cho et al., 2018). This hastens metabolic engineering of proteins and editing of useful genes that could enhance tolerance to inhibitors, or promote utilization of different substrates used for biofuel production.

inline_citations.[4609016 | Cho et al. | 2018 | Citations: The clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats/CRISPR-associated (CRISPR/Cas) adaptive immune system has been extensively used for gene editing, including gene deletion, insertion, and replacement in bacterial and eukaryotic cells owing to its simple, rapid, and efficient activities in unprecedented resolution. Furthermore, the CRISPR interference (CRISPRi) system including deactivated Cas9 (dCas9) with inactivated endonuclease activity has been further investigated for regulation of the target gene transiently or constitutively, avoiding cell death by disruption of genome. This review discusses the applications of CRISPR/Cas for genome editing in various bacterial systems and their applications. In particular, CRISPR technology has been used for the production of metabolites of high industrial significance, including biochemical, biofuel, and pharmaceutical products/precursors in bacteria. Here, we focus on methods to increase the productivity and yield/titer scan by controlling metabolic flux through individual or combinatorial use of CRISPR/Cas and CRISPRi systems with introduction of synthetic pathway in industrially common bacteria including Escherichia coli. Further, we discuss additional useful applications of the CRISPR/Cas system, including its use in functional genomics.

quotes.snippets:
In the last few decades, several new, better, and more accurate genetic tools have been developed to improve the efficiency of genome editing, such as zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs) (Doyon et al., 2011) and transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENS) (Li et al., 2011). The targeting of specific DNA sequences by ZNFs and TALENs depends on the protein-DNA interaction, and then the DNA break is introduced by FokI. However, the construction of specific DNA binding proteins is still a laborious and time-consuming task. 

Recently, the CRISPR/Cas system has revolutionized genome editing technology due to its efficiency, accuracy, and convenience (Hsu et al., 2014). This system essentially comprises a DNA endonuclease (e.g. Cas9 or Cpf1) which can bind to the target DNA sequence by the guidance of sgRNA, and then generating DNA double-strand breaks (DSB), and later the repair mechanism including HR, non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ), or microhomology-mediated end joining (MMEJ) is activated (Zetsche et al., 2015)(Burstein et al., 2016) (Figure 1A). The CRISPR/Cas system relies on the DNA-RNA recognition for inducing precise DNA cleavage, which is markerfree and capable of simultaneous multi-loci editing, thus greatly accelerates the genome editing.

inline_citations.[4462555 | Burstein et al. | 2016 | Cita: CRISPR–Cas systems provide microbes with adaptive immunity by employing short DNA sequences, termed spacers, that guide Cas proteins to cleave foreign DNA. Class 2 CRISPR–Cas systems are streamlined versions, in which a single RNA-bound Cas protein recognizes and cleaves target sequences. The programmable nature of these minimal systems has enabled researchers to repurpose them into a versatile technology that is broadly revolutionizing biological and clinical research. However, current CRISPR–Cas technologies are based solely on systems from isolated bacteria, leaving the vast majority of enzymes from organisms that have not been cultured untapped. Metagenomics, the sequencing of DNA extracted directly from natural microbial communities, provides access to the genetic material of a huge array of uncultivated organisms. Here, using genome-resolved metagenomics, we identify a number of CRISPR–Cas systems, including the first reported Cas9 in the archaeal domain of life, to our knowledge. This divergent Cas9 protein was found in little-studied nanoarchaea as part of an active CRISPR–Cas system. In bacteria, we discovered two previously unknown systems, CRISPR–CasX and CRISPR–CasY, which are among the most compact systems yet discovered. Notably, all required functional components were identified by metagenomics, enabling validation of robust in vivo RNA-guided DNA interference activity in Escherichia coli. Interrogation of environmental microbial communities combined with in vivo experiments allows us to access an unprecedented diversity of genomes, the content of which will expand the repertoire of microbe-based biotechnologies.
inline_citations.[743414 | Li et al. | 2011 | Citations:: Recent studies indicate that the DNA recognition domain of transcription activator-like (TAL) effectors can be combined with the nuclease domain of FokI restriction enzyme to produce TAL effector nucleases (TALENs) that, in pairs, bind adjacent DNA target sites and produce double-strand breaks between the target sequences, stimulating non-homologous end-joining and homologous recombination. Here, we exploit the four prevalent TAL repeats and their DNA recognition cipher to develop a ‘modular assembly’ method for rapid production of designer TALENs (dTALENs) that recognize unique DNA sequence up to 23 bases in any gene. We have used this approach to engineer 10 dTALENs to target specific loci in native yeast chromosomal genes. All dTALENs produced high rates of site-specific gene disruptions and created strains with expected mutant phenotypes. Moreover, dTALENs stimulated high rates (up to 34%) of gene replacement by homologous recombination. Finally, dTALENs caused no detectable cytotoxicity and minimal levels of undesired genetic mutations in the treated yeast strains. These studies expand the realm of verified TALEN activity from cultured human cells to an intact eukaryotic organism and suggest that low-cost, highly dependable dTALENs can assume a significant role for gene modifications of value in human and animal health, agriculture and industry.

quotes.snippets: The new generation of genome editing tools based on the CRISPR-Cas technology has the advantages of high efficiency, fast operation and high fidelity. It is the mainstream technology of multiplexed genome engineering at present, especially using the type II CRISPR-Cas9 or CRISPR-Cas12a (Cpf1) gene editing technology. For example, CRISPR-Cas9 mediated knock-in of the kasOp* for activation of silent BGCs has been reported and successfully discovered several novel pathways and NPs in Streptomyces species (Doroghazi et al., 2014). Moreover, multiplexed automated genome engineering has been reported with the capacity to simultaneously regulate the expression levels of twenty genes, and generate 4.3 billion combinatorial genomic mutations per day (Wang et al., 2009).

inline_citations.[6821899 | Doroghazi et al. | 2014 | Cit: Actinobacteria encode a wealth of natural product biosynthetic gene clusters (NPGCs), whose systematic study is complicated by numerous repetitive motifs. By combining several metrics we developed a method for global classification of these gene clusters into families (GCFs) and analyzed the biosynthetic capacity of Actinobacteria in 830 genome sequences, including 344 obtained for this project. The GCF network, comprised of 11,422 gene clusters grouped into 4,122 GCFs, was validated in hundreds of strains by correlating confident mass spectrometric detection of known small molecules with the presence/absence of their established biosynthetic gene clusters. The method also linked previously unassigned GCFs to known natural products, an approach that will enable de novo, bioassay-free discovery of novel natural products using large data sets. Extrapolation from the 830-genome dataset reveals that Actinobacteria encode hundreds of thousands of future drug leads, while the strong correlation between phylogeny and GCFs frames a roadmap to efficiently access them.

inline_citations.[231956209 | Khwatenge et al. | 2021 | C: CRISPR/Cas9 system genome editing is revolutionizing genetics research in a wide spectrum of animal models in the genetic era. Among these animals, is the poultry species. CRISPR technology is the newest and most advanced gene-editing tool that allows researchers to modify and alter gene functions for transcriptional regulation, gene targeting, epigenetic modification, gene therapy, and drug delivery in the animal genome. The applicability of the CRISPR/Cas9 system in gene editing and modification of genomes in the avian species is still emerging. Up to date, substantial progress in using CRISPR/Cas9 technology has been made in only two poultry species (chicken and quail), with chicken taking the lead. There have been major recent advances in the modification of the avian genome through their germ cell lineages. In the poultry industry, breeders and producers can utilize CRISPR-mediated approaches to enhance the many required genetic variations towards the poultry population that are absent in a given poultry flock. Thus, CRISPR allows the benefit of accessing genetic characteristics that cannot otherwise be used for poultry production. Therefore CRISPR/Cas9 becomes a very powerful and robust tool for editing genes that allow for the introduction or regulation of genetic information in poultry genomes. However, the CRISPR/Cas9 technology has several limitations that need to be addressed to enhance its use in the poultry industry. This review evaluates and provides a summary of recent advances in applying CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology in poultry research and explores its potential use in advancing poultry breeding and production with a major focus on chicken and quail. This could aid future advancements in the use of CRISPR technology to improve poultry production.

quotes.snippets: The development of molecular biological and genetic engineering methods and their enhancement as well as the rapid development of the genome editing techniques utilizing CRISPR/Cas allows researchers to set forth the targeted gene delivery to almost any selected constitutively transcribed genomic regions. This will further make it possible to dispense with the laborious screening of a large number of transgenic lines to purposefully construct highly efficient producers of recombinant proteins carrying the target genes delivered to transcriptionally active regions. The site-specific endonucleases (Cas9 being the best known) can make double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs) in a specified genomic region, which can be further repaired according to one of the two main mechanisms existing in eukaryotes: nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous DNA repair (HDR). The repair in all eukaryotes except for yeasts prevalently follows one of the variants of NHEJ pattern [7,(Demirci et al., 2018). If a template carrying a transgene is present nearby during the repair, there is a certain probability that this transgene will be knocked-in in a DSB, providing the insertion of an additional gene into the specified genomic region (Huang et al., 2019)(Rozov et al., 2019)(Collonnier et al., 2017)[12].

inline_citations.[198131435 | Rozov et al. | 2019 | Citat: The main number of genome editing events in plant objects obtained during the last decade with the help of specific nucleases zinc finger (ZFN), transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALEN), and clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas are the microindels causing frameshift and subsequent gene knock-out. The knock-ins of genes or their parts, i.e., the insertion of them into a target genome region, are between one and two orders of magnitude less frequent. First and foremost, this is associated with the specific features of the repair systems of higher eukaryotes and the availability of the donor template in accessible proximity during double-strand break (DSB) repair. This review briefs the main repair pathways in plants according to the aspect of their involvement in genome editing. The main methods for increasing the frequency of knock-ins are summarized both along the homologous recombination pathway and non-homologous end joining, which can be used for plant objects.

metadata.quote: The development of molecular biological and genetic engineering methods and their enhancement as well as the rapid development of the genome editing techniques utilizing CRISPR/Cas allows researchers to set forth the targeted gene delivery to almost any selected constitutively transcribed genomic regions. This will further make it possible to dispense with the laborious screening of a large number of transgenic lines to purposefully construct highly efficient producers of recombinant proteins carrying the target genes delivered to transcriptionally active regions. The site-specific endonucleases (Cas9 being the best known) can make double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs) in a specified genomic region, which can be further repaired according to one of the two main mechanisms existing in eukaryotes: nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous DNA repair (HDR). The repair in all eukaryotes except for yeasts prevalently follows one of the variants of NHEJ pattern [7,(Demirci et al., 2018). If a template carrying a transgene is present nearby during the repair, there is a certain probability that this transgene will be knocked-in in a DSB, providing the insertion of an additional gene into the specified genomic region (Huang et al., 2019)(Rozov et al., 2019)(Collonnier et al., 2017)[12].

quotes.snippets: The introduction of CRISPR-Cas systems has greatly boosted probiotic engineering by allowing targeted gene insertions, deletions, or alterations. This precision is essential for therapeutic probiotic development. CRISPR-Cas9 is frequently utilized because it creates double-strand breaks at precise DNA locations, which are repaired by NHEJ or HDR processes. This method allows regulated genetic alterations to improve probiotic efficacy in various applications. Engineering probiotics with targeted genome editing addresses complex disease pathways. A type I-E CRISPR-Cas system has been added to Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN), a model probiotic, to target and degrade antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) and reduce gut microbiome ARG transmission. This change promotes therapeutic efficacy and clinical safety. CRISPR systems are tailored to reduce off-target effects, ensuring therapeutic safety. Beyond Cas9, other Cas proteins like Cas12 have wider protospacer adjacent motif (PAM) compatibility, making probiotic genome targeting more flexible. The diversity of CRISPR-Cas subtypes, including type I and type II systems, expands the toolkit for editing a wide range of probiotic species, supporting the idea of probiotics as "living therapeutics" that dynamically respond to host environmental cues.

quotes.snippets: In the last few years, new approaches like Zinc finger nucleases (Carroll, 2011), Yeast Oligo-Mediated Genome Engineering (YOGE) (DiCarlo et al., 2013), transcription activator like (TAL) effector nucleases (Bogdanove et al., 2011) and the CRISPR-Cas system (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats) (DiCarlo et al., 2013)[12] have been developed for deleting or inserting genes and for controlling gene expression. The main advantages of these tools over traditional techniques lie in their efficiency, accuracy and speed. They all rely on site-specific endonucleases forming a double strand break that is repaired either with non-homologous end joining or homology-directed repair. The versatility of the methods stems from the ability to customize the DNA binding domains, allowing for site-specific genome editing. From the techniques mentioned, the use of CRISPR, together with the site specific Cas9 endonuclease, appears as the most promising tool for editing a genome at any number of different loci in a short time. Remarkably, DiCarlo et al. reported a close to 100% recombination efficiency of a linear dsDNA after transformation, together with a plasmid bearing the guiding RNA (DiCarlo et al., 2013). Similar approaches were already used for multiplex deletions of up to five genes (Jakočiūnas et al., 2015)(Mans et al., 2015). Hence, the CRISPR/Cas9 tool makes the use of marker-flanked integration cassettes obsolete and paves the way for rapid and efficient genome editing.

metadata.quote: In the last few years, new approaches like Zinc finger nucleases (Carroll, 2011), Yeast Oligo-Mediated Genome Engineering (YOGE) (DiCarlo et al., 2013), transcription activator like (TAL) effector nucleases (Bogdanove et al., 2011) and the CRISPR-Cas system (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats) (DiCarlo et al., 2013)[12] have been developed for deleting or inserting genes and for controlling gene expression. The main advantages of these tools over traditional techniques lie in their efficiency, accuracy and speed. They all rely on site-specific endonucleases forming a double strand break that is repaired either with non-homologous end joining or homology-directed repair. The versatility of the methods stems from the ability to customize the DNA binding domains, allowing for site-specific genome editing. From the techniques mentioned, the use of CRISPR, together with the site specific Cas9 endonuclease, appears as the most promising tool for editing a genome at any number of different loci in a short time. Remarkably, DiCarlo et al. reported a close to 100% recombination efficiency of a linear dsDNA after transformation, together with a plasmid bearing the guiding RNA (DiCarlo et al., 2013). Similar approaches were already used for multiplex deletions of up to five genes (Jakočiūnas et al., 2015)(Mans et al., 2015). Hence, the CRISPR/Cas9 tool makes the use of marker-flanked integration cassettes obsolete and paves the way for rapid and efficient genome editing.

quotes.snippets: Genome engineering tools have been developed to simultaneously target multiple genomic loci like as multiplex automated genome engineering (MAGE), and to precisely edit a specific genomic locus without a scar based on the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas9 system (Figure 2A). MAGE was applied to optimizing MEP pathway in E. coli for lycopene production (Wang et al., 2009). A modified method of MAGE was also successfully applied for β-carotene production in S. cerevisiae (Barbieri et al., 2017). As MAGE generates a vast of combinatorial variants in genome, it could be an effective genome engineering tool only when it is combined with a high-throughput screening (colorimetric or fluorescent) system enabling a selection of variants with desired traits. It is also difficult to incorporate large genetic parts (>1 kb) into genome by MAGE. CRISPR/Cas9 is currently powerful and popular genetic tool for precise genome editing (Jiang et al., 2013;Jessop-Fabre et al., 2016). The endonuclease Cas9 combined with guide RNA (gRNA) specifically recognizes a target site in genome, and facilitates sitespecific nucleotide base-pair mutations, gene deletions, or large DNA fragment (around 8 kb at least) insertions (Figure 2A). β-Carotene synthesis pathway was integrated into E. coli genome by CRISPR/Cas9-based method. Both MEP pathway and central metabolic pathways were optimized in the engineered strain, and the final strain was cultured in fed-batch, yielding 2.0 g/L of β-carotene (Li et al., 2015). A set of genomic loci of Y. lipolytica have been identified for targeted marker-less integration using CRISPR/Cas9 (Schwartz et al., 2017). An automated platform for multiplex genome-scale engineering in S. cerevisiae has been also developed based on CRISPR/Cas9 (Si et al., 2017).

quotes.snippets: Although tools in E. coli is relatively abundant compared to many other host organisms, CRISPR-Cas still greatly propels our capability to engineer E. coli. Such capabilities have largely facilitated metabolic engineering and proved to improve the titers, productivities and yields for various chemicals. Compared to the previously available tools, CRISPR-Cas-based systems have a few advantages that have been exploited in various applications. sections.title: Introduction to CRISPR/Cas9 and Advanced Genetic Engineering Tools
sections.tldr: CRISPR/Cas9 and other advanced genetic engineering tools have revolutionized genome editing in microbial systems like E. coli and yeast. These technologies offer unprecedented precision, efficiency, and multiplexing capabilities compared to earlier methods, making them powerful tools for recombinant protein expression optimization. sections.text:
Genetic engineering has undergone a remarkable transformation with the development of increasingly precise and efficient genome editing tools. Before the current era of targeted nucleases, researchers relied on more cumbersome methods to modify microbial genomes. The landscape dramatically changed with the introduction of programmable nucleases, including Zinc Finger Nucleases (ZFNs), transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs), and most recently, CRISPR/Cas systems. <Paper corpusId="236320664" paperTitle="(Abaandou et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

While ZFNs and TALENs represented significant advances, they relied on protein-DNA interactions for targeting, making their construction labor-intensive and time-consuming. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="743414" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> The emergence of CRISPR/Cas systems, particularly CRISPR/Cas9, has revolutionized genome editing due to its RNA-guided DNA targeting mechanism, which offers superior efficiency, accuracy, and convenience. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> Unlike its predecessors, CRISPR/Cas9 utilizes RNA-DNA recognition for precise DNA cleavage, enabling marker-free editing and simultaneous modification of multiple genetic loci. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

These advanced tools have dramatically enhanced our ability to engineer the genomes of key industrial microorganisms, particularly Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Escherichia coli. <Paper corpusId="20877207" paperTitle="(Tian et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="14967661" paperTitle="(Mans et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="17110997" paperTitle="(Zerbini et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> The CRISPR/Cas9 system has been widely adopted due to its high efficiency, operational simplicity, and exceptional fidelity. <Paper corpusId="244390593" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> Type II CRISPR-Cas9 and CRISPR-Cas12a (Cpf1) technologies have become mainstream approaches for multiplexed genome engineering, facilitating sophisticated genetic manipulations that were previously unattainable. <Paper corpusId="244390593" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

The impact of these technologies extends beyond single gene modifications. Advanced genome editing tools now enable researchers to simultaneously regulate the expression of multiple genes and generate billions of combinatorial genomic mutations rapidly. <Paper corpusId="244390593" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> These capabilities have significantly streamlined the exploration of gene functions and manipulation of expression systems, providing unprecedented opportunities for optimizing recombinant protein production. <Paper corpusId="253841294" paperTitle="(Pan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

snippets:
In the last few decades, several new, better, and more accurate genetic tools have been developed to improve the efficiency of genome editing, such as zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs) (Doyon et al., 2011) and transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENS) (Li et al., 2011). The targeting of specific DNA sequences by ZNFs and TALENs depends on the protein-DNA interaction, and then the DNA break is introduced by FokI. However, the construction of specific DNA binding proteins is still a laborious and time-consuming task. 

Recently, the CRISPR/Cas system has revolutionized genome editing technology due to its efficiency, accuracy, and convenience (Hsu et al., 2014). This system essentially comprises a DNA endonuclease (e.g. Cas9 or Cpf1) which can bind to the target DNA sequence by the guidance of sgRNA, and then generating DNA double-strand breaks (DSB), and later the repair mechanism including HR, non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ), or microhomology-mediated end joining (MMEJ) is activated (Zetsche et al., 2015)(Burstein et al., 2016) (Figure 1A). The CRISPR/Cas system relies on the DNA-RNA recognition for inducing precise DNA cleavage, which is markerfree and capable of simultaneous multi-loci editing, thus greatly accelerates the genome editing.

snippets: Recent studies indicate that the DNA recognition domain of transcription activator-like (TAL) effectors can be combined with the nuclease domain of FokI restriction enzyme to produce TAL effector nucleases (TALENs) that, in pairs, bind adjacent DNA target sites and produce double-strand breaks between the target sequences, stimulating non-homologous end-joining and homologous recombination. Here, we exploit the four prevalent TAL repeats and their DNA recognition cipher to develop a ‘modular assembly’ method for rapid production of designer TALENs (dTALENs) that recognize unique DNA sequence up to 23 bases in any gene. We have used this approach to engineer 10 dTALENs to target specific loci in native yeast chromosomal genes. All dTALENs produced high rates of site-specific gene disruptions and created strains with expected mutant phenotypes. Moreover, dTALENs stimulated high rates (up to 34%) of gene replacement by homologous recombination. Finally, dTALENs caused no detectable cytotoxicity and minimal levels of undesired genetic mutations in the treated yeast strains. These studies expand the realm of verified TALEN activity from cultured human cells to an intact eukaryotic organism and suggest that low-cost, highly dependable dTALENs can assume a significant role for gene modifications of value in human and animal health, agriculture and industry.

snippets: A variety of techniques for strain engineering in Saccharomyces cerevisiae have recently been developed. However, especially when multiple genetic manipulations are required, strain construction is still a time-consuming process. This study describes new CRISPR/Cas9-based approaches for easy, fast strain construction in yeast and explores their potential for simultaneous introduction of multiple genetic modifications. An open-source tool (http://yeastriction.tnw.tudelft.nl) is presented for identification of suitable Cas9 target sites in S. cerevisiae strains. A transformation strategy, using in vivo assembly of a guideRNA plasmid and subsequent genetic modification, was successfully implemented with high accuracies. An alternative strategy, using in vitro assembled plasmids containing two gRNAs, was used to simultaneously introduce up to six genetic modifications in a single transformation step with high efficiencies. Where previous studies mainly focused on the use of CRISPR/Cas9 for gene inactivation, we demonstrate the versatility of CRISPR/Cas9-based engineering of yeast by achieving simultaneous integration of a multigene construct combined with gene deletion and the simultaneous introduction of two single-nucleotide mutations at different loci. Sets of standardized plasmids, as well as the web-based Yeastriction target-sequence identifier and primer-design tool, are made available to the yeast research community to facilitate fast, standardized and efficient application of the CRISPR/Cas9 system.

snippets: BackgroundThe exploitation of the CRISPR/Cas9 machinery coupled to lambda (λ) recombinase-mediated homologous recombination (recombineering) is becoming the method of choice for genome editing in E. coli. First proposed by Jiang and co-workers, the strategy has been subsequently fine-tuned by several authors who demonstrated, by using few selected loci, that the efficiency of mutagenesis (number of mutant colonies over total number of colonies analyzed) can be extremely high (up to 100%). However, from published data it is difficult to appreciate the robustness of the technology, defined as the number of successfully mutated loci over the total number of targeted loci. This information is particularly relevant in high-throughput genome editing, where repetition of experiments to rescue missing mutants would be impractical. This work describes a "brute force" validation activity, which culminated in the definition of a robust, simple and rapid protocol for single or multiple gene deletions.ResultsWe first set up our own version of the CRISPR/Cas9 protocol and then we evaluated the mutagenesis efficiency by changing different parameters including sequence of guide RNAs, length and concentration of donor DNAs, and use of single stranded and double stranded donor DNAs. We then validated the optimized conditions targeting 78 "dispensable" genes. This work led to the definition of a protocol, featuring the use of double stranded synthetic donor DNAs, which guarantees mutagenesis efficiencies consistently higher than 10% and a robustness of 100%. The procedure can be applied also for simultaneous gene deletions.ConclusionsThis work defines for the first time the robustness of a CRISPR/Cas9-based protocol based on a large sample size. Since the technical solutions here proposed can be applied to other similar procedures, the data could be of general interest for the scientific community working on bacterial genome editing and, in particular, for those involved in synthetic biology projects requiring high throughput procedures.

sections.tldr: CRISPR/Cas9 functions through RNA-guided DNA targeting that recognizes specific sequences adjacent to PAM sites, enabling precise genome editing without marker integration. This system offers unprecedented technical advantages over previous methods including simplified design, high efficiency, marker-free editing, and multiplexing capabilities. (15 sources)
sections.text:
The CRISPR/Cas9 system operates through a distinct molecular mechanism that contributes to its exceptional utility in microbial systems. The system's functionality depends on small CRISPR RNAs (crRNAs) that work in conjunction with trans-activating crRNAs (tracrRNAs) to guide the Cas9 nuclease to target DNA sequences, which must be adjacent to a protospacer-adjacent motif (PAM) with the sequence NGG. Recognition occurs through alignment of 12-15 nucleotides at the 3' end of the crRNA with the target DNA sequence. <Paper corpusId="104386515" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

Unlike previous genome editing technologies like zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs) and transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs) that rely on protein-DNA interactions, CRISPR/Cas9 utilizes RNA-DNA recognition. This fundamental difference enables a far simpler application approach - researchers can target any genomic location by simply changing the guide RNA sequence without having to engineer new proteins. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> This ease of programming has been described as giving researchers a "Swiss army knife" for molecular biology. <Paper corpusId="229722805" paperTitle="(Rainha et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="14967661" paperTitle="(Mans et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>

When the Cas9-sgRNA complex binds to the target DNA sequence, the endonuclease activity of Cas9 creates a double-strand break (DSB) at the target site. <Paper corpusId="230797058" paperTitle="(Adegboye et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4609016" paperTitle="(Cho et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> These breaks are then repaired by cellular mechanisms including non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), homologous DNA repair (HDR), or microhomology-mediated end joining (MMEJ). <Paper corpusId="248255640" paperTitle="(Rozov et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="198131435" paperTitle="(Rozov et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> The precision of this system has enabled researchers to perform gene deletions, insertions, and even point mutations with remarkable specificity. <Paper corpusId="104386515" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

One of the most significant technical advantages of CRISPR/Cas9 is the ability to perform marker-free genomic modifications. Traditional strain engineering methods require selectable markers for each genetic modification, and their subsequent elimination (marker recovery) is a time-consuming bottleneck, often requiring five or more days even in fast-growing yeast cultures. <Paper corpusId="261005360" paperTitle="(Yuzbashev et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="11786951" paperTitle="(Jessop-Fabre et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> By eliminating the need for marker integration, CRISPR/Cas9 dramatically accelerates the strain engineering process.

The efficiency of CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing in microbial systems is remarkable. DiCarlo et al. reported nearly 100% recombination efficiency of linear dsDNA when co-transformed with a plasmid carrying the guide RNA. <Paper corpusId="5282362" paperTitle="(Kavscek et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="665503" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> This extraordinary efficiency allows researchers to skip multiple steps in traditional strain construction protocols, such as Escherichia coli transformation and verification steps. <Paper corpusId="229722805" paperTitle="(Rainha et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="215711867" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

Another major advantage is the system's capability for multiplexed genome editing, allowing simultaneous modification of multiple genetic loci in a single transformation step. This feature has enabled researchers to perform up to six genetic modifications simultaneously with high efficiencies. <Paper corpusId="5282362" paperTitle="(Kavscek et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="14967661" paperTitle="(Mans et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> This multiplexing capacity significantly decreases the time required for complex genetic modifications when building microbial cell factories. <Paper corpusId="229722805" paperTitle="(Rainha et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

The versatility of CRISPR/Cas9 has facilitated its application in transcriptional control, gene targeting, epigenetic modification, and therapeutic applications. <Paper corpusId="245281587" paperTitle="(Sharma et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231956209" paperTitle="(Khwatenge et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> This versatility has accelerated metabolic engineering of microorganisms for enhanced tolerance to inhibitors and improved utilization of different substrates, particularly important for industrial bioproduction applications. <Paper corpusId="230797058" paperTitle="(Adegboye et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4609016" paperTitle="(Cho et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

snippets: Recently, there has been growing evidence that the CRISPR/Cas9-based genome editing approach enables efficient, intricately controlled gene expression and versatile cross-species genome editing in various micro-organisms (Jiang et al., 2016)(Jakočiūnas et al., 2016)(Sander et al., 2014). Briefly, the action mechanism of the CRISPR/Cas9 system is that the complex of small crRNAs produced by the coordinated action of a small, trans-activating crRNA (tracrRNA), the Cas9 nuclease, and the host RNaseIII directs Cas9 to cleave the target DNA, which is followed by an adjacent protospacer-adjacent motif (PAM). The target DNA is recognized by its alignment with the 12-15 nucleotides at the 3 end of the crRNA guide sequence as well as the NGG sequence of PAM. Unlike the effort to manipulate other transcription factors, the CRISPR/Cas9 system can be simply applied to genome editing and metabolic pathway engineering by only altering the target sequence without any protein engineering. For example, Jiang et al. reported the introduction of point mutations and codon changes in the E. coli genome using the CRISPR/Cas9 method (Jiang et al., 2016). For instance, the β-carotene biosynthetic pathway, the methylerythritol-phosphate pathway, and the central metabolic pathways in E. coli were systematically optimized for β-carotene production by iterative editing of the 2-day editing cycle, and the best production was 2.0 g/L β-carotene (fed-batch fermentation) (Li et al., 2015).

snippets: The clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats/CRISPR-associated (CRISPR/Cas) adaptive immune system has been extensively used for gene editing, including gene deletion, insertion, and replacement in bacterial and eukaryotic cells owing to its simple, rapid, and efficient activities in unprecedented resolution. Furthermore, the CRISPR interference (CRISPRi) system including deactivated Cas9 (dCas9) with inactivated endonuclease activity has been further investigated for regulation of the target gene transiently or constitutively, avoiding cell death by disruption of genome. This review discusses the applications of CRISPR/Cas for genome editing in various bacterial systems and their applications. In particular, CRISPR technology has been used for the production of metabolites of high industrial significance, including biochemical, biofuel, and pharmaceutical products/precursors in bacteria. Here, we focus on methods to increase the productivity and yield/titer scan by controlling metabolic flux through individual or combinatorial use of CRISPR/Cas and CRISPRi systems with introduction of synthetic pathway in industrially common bacteria including Escherichia coli. Further, we discuss additional useful applications of the CRISPR/Cas system, including its use in functional genomics.

snippets: The development of molecular biological and genetic engineering methods and their enhancement as well as the rapid development of the genome editing techniques utilizing CRISPR/Cas allows researchers to set forth the targeted gene delivery to almost any selected constitutively transcribed genomic regions. This will further make it possible to dispense with the laborious screening of a large number of transgenic lines to purposefully construct highly efficient producers of recombinant proteins carrying the target genes delivered to transcriptionally active regions. The site-specific endonucleases (Cas9 being the best known) can make double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs) in a specified genomic region, which can be further repaired according to one of the two main mechanisms existing in eukaryotes: nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous DNA repair (HDR). The repair in all eukaryotes except for yeasts prevalently follows one of the variants of NHEJ pattern [7,(Demirci et al., 2018). If a template carrying a transgene is present nearby during the repair, there is a certain probability that this transgene will be knocked-in in a DSB, providing the insertion of an additional gene into the specified genomic region (Huang et al., 2019)(Rozov et al., 2019)(Collonnier et al., 2017)[12].

snippets: The main number of genome editing events in plant objects obtained during the last decade with the help of specific nucleases zinc finger (ZFN), transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALEN), and clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/Cas are the microindels causing frameshift and subsequent gene knock-out. The knock-ins of genes or their parts, i.e., the insertion of them into a target genome region, are between one and two orders of magnitude less frequent. First and foremost, this is associated with the specific features of the repair systems of higher eukaryotes and the availability of the donor template in accessible proximity during double-strand break (DSB) repair. This review briefs the main repair pathways in plants according to the aspect of their involvement in genome editing. The main methods for increasing the frequency of knock-ins are summarized both along the homologous recombination pathway and non-homologous end joining, which can be used for plant objects.

One of the most important advantages of CRISPR is that, due to its high efficiency, it allows markerless genomic modifications. During traditional strain engineering, the elimination of selectable markers from the genome, known as marker recovery, is a common bottleneck (Tsai et al., 2015) . Even fast-growing yeast cultures require at least five days for marker recovery (Jessop-Fabre et al., 2016) , while integrative transformation itself takes only two or three. snippets: Abstract Saccharomyces cerevisiae is an established industrial host for production of recombinant proteins, fuels and chemicals. To enable stable integration of multiple marker‐free overexpression cassettes in the genome of S. cerevisiae, we have developed a vector toolkit EasyClone‐MarkerFree. The integration of linearized expression cassettes into defined genomic loci is facilitated by CRISPR/Cas9. Cas9 is recruited to the chromosomal location by specific guide RNAs (gRNAs) expressed from a set of gRNA helper vectors. Using our genome engineering vector suite, single and triple insertions are obtained with 90–100% and 60–70% targeting efficiency, respectively. We demonstrate application of the vector toolkit by constructing a haploid laboratory strain (CEN.PK113‐7D) and a diploid industrial strain (Ethanol Red) for production of 3‐hydroxypropionic acid, where we tested three different acetyl‐CoA supply strategies, requiring overexpression of three to six genes each. Among the tested strategies was a bacterial cytosolic pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which was integrated into the genome in a single transformation. snippets: In the last few years, new approaches like Zinc finger nucleases (Carroll, 2011), Yeast Oligo-Mediated Genome Engineering (YOGE) (DiCarlo et al., 2013), transcription activator like (TAL) effector nucleases (Bogdanove et al., 2011) and the CRISPR-Cas system (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats) (DiCarlo et al., 2013)[12] have been developed for deleting or inserting genes and for controlling gene expression. The main advantages of these tools over traditional techniques lie in their efficiency, accuracy and speed. They all rely on site-specific endonucleases forming a double strand break that is repaired either with non-homologous end joining or homology-directed repair. The versatility of the methods stems from the ability to customize the DNA binding domains, allowing for site-specific genome editing. From the techniques mentioned, the use of CRISPR, together with the site specific Cas9 endonuclease, appears as the most promising tool for editing a genome at any number of different loci in a short time. Remarkably, DiCarlo et al. reported a close to 100% recombination efficiency of a linear dsDNA after transformation, together with a plasmid bearing the guiding RNA (DiCarlo et al., 2013). Similar approaches were already used for multiplex deletions of up to five genes (Jakočiūnas et al., 2015)(Mans et al., 2015). Hence, the CRISPR/Cas9 tool makes the use of marker-flanked integration cassettes obsolete and paves the way for rapid and efficient genome editing.

snippets: Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) and CRISPR-associated (Cas) systems in bacteria and archaea use RNA-guided nuclease activity to provide adaptive immunity against invading foreign nucleic acids. Here, we report the use of type II bacterial CRISPR-Cas system in Saccharomyces cerevisiae for genome engineering. The CRISPR-Cas components, Cas9 gene and a designer genome targeting CRISPR guide RNA (gRNA), show robust and specific RNA-guided endonuclease activity at targeted endogenous genomic loci in yeast. Using constitutive Cas9 expression and a transient gRNA cassette, we show that targeted double-strand breaks can increase homologous recombination rates of single- and double-stranded oligonucleotide donors by 5-fold and 130-fold, respectively. In addition, co-transformation of a gRNA plasmid and a donor DNA in cells constitutively expressing Cas9 resulted in near 100% donor DNA recombination frequency. Our approach provides foundations for a simple and powerful genome engineering tool for site-specific mutagenesis and allelic replacement in yeast.

snippets: With rapid progress in DNA synthesis and sequencing, strain engineering starts to be the rate-limiting step in synthetic biology. Here, we report a gRNA-tRNA array for CRISPR-Cas9 (GTR-CRISPR) for multiplexed engineering of Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Using reported gRNAs shown to be effective, this system enables simultaneous disruption of 8 genes with 87% efficiency. snippets: CRISPR/Cas9 system genome editing is revolutionizing genetics research in a wide spectrum of animal models in the genetic era. Among these animals, is the poultry species. CRISPR technology is the newest and most advanced gene-editing tool that allows researchers to modify and alter gene functions for transcriptional regulation, gene targeting, epigenetic modification, gene therapy, and drug delivery in the animal genome. The applicability of the CRISPR/Cas9 system in gene editing and modification of genomes in the avian species is still emerging. Up to date, substantial progress in using CRISPR/Cas9 technology has been made in only two poultry species (chicken and quail), with chicken taking the lead. There have been major recent advances in the modification of the avian genome through their germ cell lineages. In the poultry industry, breeders and producers can utilize CRISPR-mediated approaches to enhance the many required genetic variations towards the poultry population that are absent in a given poultry flock. Thus, CRISPR allows the benefit of accessing genetic characteristics that cannot otherwise be used for poultry production. Therefore CRISPR/Cas9 becomes a very powerful and robust tool for editing genes that allow for the introduction or regulation of genetic information in poultry genomes. However, the CRISPR/Cas9 technology has several limitations that need to be addressed to enhance its use in the poultry industry. This review evaluates and provides a summary of recent advances in applying CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing technology in poultry research and explores its potential use in advancing poultry breeding and production with a major focus on chicken and quail. This could aid future advancements in the use of CRISPR technology to improve poultry production.

sections.title: Efficiency Improvements in Genome Editing
sections.tldr: CRISPR/Cas systems have dramatically increased genome editing efficiency in microbial hosts, enabling near-perfect success rates for gene modifications and reducing engineering timelines from weeks to days. These improvements come from optimized delivery systems, multiplexed editing capabilities, and elimination of selection marker requirements. (13 sources)
sections.text:
The advent of CRISPR/Cas technologies has fundamentally transformed the efficiency of genetic engineering in microbial systems. Traditional genetic modification methods in both E. coli and yeast often suffered from low editing efficiencies and time-consuming procedures. CRISPR/Cas9 has dramatically improved these metrics, with DiCarlo et al. reporting nearly 100% recombination efficiency when using linear DNA co-transformed with a guide RNA plasmid in yeast. <Paper corpusId="665503" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> This extraordinary efficiency has made it possible to achieve double-strand break-mediated homologous recombination at rates 5-fold higher for single-stranded oligonucleotides and 130-fold higher for double-stranded donors. <Paper corpusId="665503" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>

In E. coli, researchers have developed optimized CRISPR/Cas9 systems that significantly improve editing efficiency while reducing operational time. One such system combines the λ-Red recombineering machinery with Cas9 under control of an inducible promoter, enabling nearly 100% efficiency for both codon replacements and gene knockouts within just two days. <Paper corpusId="210921434" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> These improved systems use triple-plasmid approaches that coordinate expression of Cas9, guide RNAs, and donor DNA templates to minimize metabolic burden while maximizing editing efficiency.

For Saccharomyces cerevisiae, recent optimization efforts have yielded impressive results. Singh et al. reported a CRISPR-Cas9 strategy for targeted chromosomal integration with 74% efficiency across multiple genomic loci, while also demonstrating that even short 15 bp microhomology arms are sufficient to achieve 50% knock-in efficiency. <Paper corpusId="255475133" paperTitle="(Singh et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> Beyond Cas9, other CRISPR-associated nucleases have been adapted for genome editing, including the Cas12a-like MAD7 nuclease, which enables efficient generation of single nucleotide polymorphisms and gene deletions in E. coli. <Paper corpusId="257581463" paperTitle="(Mund et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

One of the most significant advantages of CRISPR-based editing is the elimination of selectable markers. Traditional strain engineering requires marker integration and subsequent removal, a process that can take five or more days even in fast-growing yeast cultures. <Paper corpusId="261005360" paperTitle="(Yuzbashev et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="11786951" paperTitle="(Jessop-Fabre et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> By enabling marker-free genomic modifications, CRISPR technologies dramatically accelerate strain development cycles.

The efficiency improvements extend to multiplexed genome editing as well. Zhang et al. developed a sgRNA-tRNA array system for CRISPR-Cas9 that allows simultaneous editing of up to 8 genes with 87% efficiency in yeast. <Paper corpusId="215711867" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="255185494" paperTitle="(Holland et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> This multiplexing capability has been further enhanced by approaches like the "Lightning GTR-CRISPR" method, which avoids cloning steps in E. coli by directly transforming Golden Gate reaction mixtures into yeast, enabling disruption of 6 genes in just 3 days. <Paper corpusId="215711867" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

The high-throughput capabilities of CRISPR systems have enabled array-based oligonucleotide technologies that can create hundreds of thousands of cassettes containing donor templates and genome-targeting gRNAs. These pooled plasmid libraries can generate designed mutations in parallel, with each plasmid serving as a genetic barcode trackable through next-generation sequencing. <Paper corpusId="227168518" paperTitle="(Lacerda et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> This approach has been successfully applied to improve traits like ethanol tolerance in S. cerevisiae by simultaneously perturbing multiple regulatory genes with tens of thousands of mutations.

Beyond traditional applications, CRISPR-based precision has been utilized for specific base editing applications, such as targeted adenine-to-cytosine conversions in E. coli to investigate metabolic functions. <Paper corpusId="278182933" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10654542" paperTitle="(Kui et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> Similarly, CRISPR systems have been adapted for engineering probiotics, creating double-strand breaks at precise DNA locations that can be repaired through non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or homology-directed repair (HDR) processes. <Paper corpusId="276943704" paperTitle="(Bhatia et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

For complex genetic constructs, CRISPR-based methods have dramatically simplified the process. Rationally building heterologous genetic modules in yeast previously presented challenges, especially for multi-gene systems where the fitness of intermediate genotypes was unknown. <Paper corpusId="249873250" paperTitle="(Abdullah et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> Modern CRISPR-based approaches have overcome these limitations, providing highly scalable and combinatorial genome editing technologies.

snippets: The CRISPR/Cas9 system greatly improved the efficiency of genetic engineering. To improve the genetic engineering efficiency, Jiang et al. construct a triple-plasmid system as mentioned above. This novel genetic engineering tool significantly improved the efficiency of genetic modification and thus accelerated the development of industrial biology. In previous studies, Cas9 and gRNA were expressed in two plasmids, respectively, as the simultaneous expression would burden the organism metabolism and cause cell death. Hence, Cas9 or gRNA should be repressed before a genome editing event. Cas9 and gRNA can be assembled into one plasmid containing a pBAD promoter, which is repressed by glucose and induced by arabinose and a temperature-sensitive replicon repA101ts, so that transformed E. coli could grow on glucoseamended plates and be edited under the induction with 2 g/L of arabinose. This fast and easy procedure for genome editing could perform continuously, as multiple loci only required one plasmid construction and one step of transformation. To further improve the simultaneous editing efficiency of multiple loci, a CRISPR/Cas9-assisted multiplex genome editing technique was developed. The CRISPR/Cas9-assisted multiplex genome editing technique contained three plasmids: pRedCas9 containing both λ-Red recombineering and Cas9 system under the control of pBAD promoter, pMgRNAs containing gRNAs, and pDonorDNAs carrying multiple donor DNA cassettes (Feng et al., 2018)

Comparing to the previously established system, this optimized system has a higher gene editing efficiency and less operating time, almost 100% for codon replacements and knockout genes within 2 days.

After CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing, each plasmid can be served as a genetic barcode and the frequency of each designed mutation can be tracked by next-generation sequencing (NGS). This approach was applied to improve ethanol tolerance and production in S. cerevisiae by perturbing 25 regulatory genes with 43,020 mutations (Liu et al., 2019). Also, genetic parts encoding overexpression and knockdown mutations of >90% yeast genes were iteratively integrated into the repetitive genomic sequences in a modular manner based on multiplex integration by CRISPR/Cas9. This approach with the aid of robotic automation allowed functional mapping and multiplex optimization on a genome scale for diverse phenotypes such as acetic acid tolerance (Zhao et al., 2018). A unique advantage of the CRISPR/Cas9 system is that multiple gRNAs can be combined with Cas9, achieving efficient multiplex genome editing. The system could accelerate future genome-scale engineering in polyploid industrial strains (Zhao et al., 2018). Furthermore, the use of lab-on-chip, ultra-low volume nanoreactors allows for high index of selection of variants (Vervoort et al., 2017).

snippets: Orchidaceae is the second largest family of flowering plants, which is highly valued for its ornamental purposes and medicinal uses. Dendrobium officinale is a special orchid species that can grow without seed vernalization. Because the whole-genome sequence of D. officinale is publicly available, this species is poised to become a convenient research model for the evolutionary, developmental, and genetic studies of Orchidaceae. Despite these advantages, the methods of genetic manipulation are poorly developed in D. officinale. In this study, based on the previously developed Agrobacterium-mediated gene transformation system, we identified several highly efficient promoters for exogenous gene expression and successfully applied the CRISPR/Cas9 system for editing endogenous genes in the genome of D. officinale. These two basic techniques contribute to the genetic manipulation toolbox of Orchidaceae. The pCambia-1301-35SN vector containing the CaMV 35S promoter and the β-glucuronidase (GUS) and Superfolder green fluorescence protein (SG) as reporter genes were introduced into the plant tissues by the Agrobacterium-mediated transformation system. Fluorescence emission from the transformed plants confirmed the successful transcription and translation of SG genes into functional proteins. We compared the GUS activity under different promoters including four commonly used promoters (MtHP, CVMV, MMV and PCISV) with CaMV 35S promoter and found that MMV, CVMV, and PCISV were as effective as the 35S promoter. Furthermore, we applied the CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genome editing system successfully in D. officinale. By selecting five target genes (C3H, C4H, 4CL, CCR, and IRX) in the lignocellulose biosynthesis pathway, we showed that, for a given target, this system can generate edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) at a rate of 10 to 100%. These results showed that our two genetic manipulation tools can efficiently express exogenous genes and edit endogenous genes in D. officinale. These efficient research tools will not only help create novel D. officinale varieties, but will also facilitate the molecular genetic investigation of orchid biology.

A type I-E CRISPR-Cas system has been added to Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN), a model probiotic, to target and degrade antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) and reduce gut microbiome ARG transmission. Beyond Cas9, other Cas proteins like Cas12 have wider protospacer adjacent motif (PAM) compatibility, making probiotic genome targeting more flexible. sections.title: Multiplex and High-Throughput Capabilities
sections.tldr: CRISPR-based systems have enabled unprecedented multiplexing capabilities, allowing simultaneous modification of up to 20 genes and generation of billions of genomic variants daily. These high-throughput approaches have transformed strain engineering through array-based technologies, pooled libraries, and automated platforms that dramatically accelerate the development of optimized production strains. (10 sources)
sections.text:
The transformative impact of CRISPR/Cas systems in microbial engineering is perhaps most evident in their multiplexing capabilities, which extend far beyond what was possible with traditional genetic engineering approaches. CRISPR-based technologies have enabled researchers to simultaneously regulate the expression of up to twenty genes and generate an astonishing 4.3 billion combinatorial genomic mutations per day <Paper corpusId="244390593" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This remarkable capability represents a quantum leap in genetic engineering throughput compared to pre-CRISPR methodologies.

In E. coli and S. cerevisiae, researchers have developed a suite of multiplex pathway-optimization techniques that leverage CRISPR systems, including MAGE, YOGE, TRMR, RAGE, CREATE, and CHAnGE. These approaches have dramatically enhanced the ability to engineer complex pathways by enabling simultaneous modification of multiple genetic loci <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, the CHAnGE system utilizes CRISPR/Cas9 and single-nucleotide-mediated homology-directed repair to rapidly evolve yeast strains on a genome-wide scale, significantly improving tolerance to growth inhibitors <Paper corpusId="276697152" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

To improve efficiency while reducing operational complexity, researchers have developed sophisticated plasmid systems for multiplex genome editing. One notable approach is the triple-plasmid system in E. coli that combines λ-Red recombineering machinery with Cas9 under an inducible promoter. This optimized system achieves nearly 100% efficiency for both codon replacements and gene knockouts within just two days <Paper corpusId="210921434" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. The system uses separate plasmids for Cas9/λ-Red (pRedCas9), guide RNAs (pMgRNAs), and donor DNA cassettes (pDonorDNAs), enabling simultaneous editing of multiple loci with a single transformation step <Paper corpusId="210921434" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The multiplexing capabilities of CRISPR systems have been extended through innovative approaches like homology-integrated CRISPR (HI-CRISPR), which enables insertion of 100-bp mutagenized homologous recombination donors for multiple gene knockouts and genome evolution <Paper corpusId="276697152" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, the CasPER system combines error-prone PCR with Cas9-mediated genome editing to integrate large-scale donor-mediated variant libraries into multiple genomic sites with efficiencies approaching 100% <Paper corpusId="276697152" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

Perhaps most exciting is the development of high-throughput CRISPR-based technologies for genotype-phenotype discovery. Array-based oligonucleotide technologies now enable the creation of hundreds of thousands of cassettes containing donor templates and genome-targeting gRNAs. These pooled plasmid libraries generate designed mutations in parallel, with each plasmid serving as a genetic barcode that can be tracked through next-generation sequencing <Paper corpusId="227168518" paperTitle="(Lacerda et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach has been successfully applied to improve ethanol tolerance in S. cerevisiae by simultaneously perturbing 25 regulatory genes with over 43,000 mutations <Paper corpusId="227168518" paperTitle="(Lacerda et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The scalability of CRISPR-based multiplexing has led to the development of fully automated platforms for genome-scale engineering. Si et al. developed an automated system that uses CRISPR-Cas and a full-length cDNA library to perform multiplex genome engineering in a completely automated manner <Paper corpusId="276697152" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, genetic parts encoding overexpression and knockdown mutations of more than 90% of yeast genes have been iteratively integrated into repetitive genomic sequences using multiplex CRISPR/Cas9 integration, allowing functional mapping and optimization on a genome scale for diverse phenotypes such as acetic acid tolerance <Paper corpusId="227168518" paperTitle="(Lacerda et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4461675" paperTitle="(Zhao et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Beyond traditional strain engineering applications, CRISPR-based multiplexing has been leveraged for novel natural product discovery. For example, CRISPR-Cas9 mediated knock-in of kasOp* has been used to activate silent biosynthetic gene clusters in Streptomyces species, successfully uncovering several novel pathways and natural products <Paper corpusId="244390593" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6821899" paperTitle="(Doroghazi et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

Traditional approaches required selection markers for each modification, whereas CRISPR systems allow multiple edits without marker integration or recycling, dramatically improving engineering throughput <Paper corpusId="53020678" paperTitle="(Yao et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. The efficiency, precision, and marker-free nature of CRISPR-Cas systems have made them invaluable for metabolic engineering applications, particularly for optimizing the MEP pathway for compounds like lycopene and β-carotene in E. coli and S. cerevisiae <Paper corpusId="52962258" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

These advances, along with dynamic promoter expression systems (DPESs), have facilitated precise up- and down-regulation of heterologous metabolic pathways not only in yeast but also in other microbial systems like Bacillus subtilis and E. coli <Paper corpusId="263721852" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: The optimization of engineered metabolic pathways requires careful control over the levels and timing of metabolic enzyme expression. Optogenetic tools are ideal for achieving such precise control, as light can be applied and removed instantly without complex media changes. Here we show that light-controlled transcription can be used to enhance the biosynthesis of valuable products in engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We introduce new optogenetic circuits to shift cells from a light-induced growth phase to a darkness-induced production phase, which allows us to control fermentation with only light. Furthermore, optogenetic control of engineered pathways enables a new mode of bioreactor operation using periodic light pulses to tune enzyme expression during the production phase of fermentation to increase yields. Using these advances, we control the mitochondrial isobutanol pathway to produce up to 8.49 ± 0.31 g l−1 of isobutanol and 2.38 ± 0.06 g l−1 of 2-methyl-1-butanol micro-aerobically from glucose. These results make a compelling case for the application of optogenetics to metabolic engineering for the production of valuable products.

snippets: Actinobacteria encode a wealth of natural product biosynthetic gene clusters (NPGCs), whose systematic study is complicated by numerous repetitive motifs. By combining several metrics we developed a method for global classification of these gene clusters into families (GCFs) and analyzed the biosynthetic capacity of Actinobacteria in 830 genome sequences, including 344 obtained for this project. The GCF network, comprised of 11,422 gene clusters grouped into 4,122 GCFs, was validated in hundreds of strains by correlating confident mass spectrometric detection of known small molecules with the presence/absence of their established biosynthetic gene clusters. The method also linked previously unassigned GCFs to known natural products, an approach that will enable de novo, bioassay-free discovery of novel natural products using large data sets. Extrapolation from the 830-genome dataset reveals that Actinobacteria encode hundreds of thousands of future drug leads, while the strong correlation between phylogeny and GCFs frames a roadmap to efficiently access them.

sections.title: Specific Applications in Recombinant Protein Expression
sections.tldr: CRISPR/Cas9 has enabled precise genetic modifications that significantly enhance recombinant protein expression in microbial systems. These applications include integrating expression systems directly into host chromosomes, optimizing metabolic pathways, and developing controllable expression platforms for industrial production. (6 sources)
sections.text:
CRISPR/Cas9 technology has revolutionized recombinant protein expression through targeted chromosomal integrations that enhance expression stability and control. A notable example is the successful integration of the T7 RNA Polymerase gene under control of the lacUV5 promoter into the Escherichia coli BW25113 genome. This genetic modification created a new strain (BW25113-T7) that maintained the original strain's advantages, including rapid growth rate, while enabling efficient and controllable protein expression using the T7 Expression System. <Paper corpusId="233703833" paperTitle="(Ye et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> The modified strain demonstrated practical applications in metabolic engineering, successfully producing 5-Aminolevulinic Acid via the C5 pathway and establishing a foundation for enhanced controllability through the development of a T7 Promoter Variants Library. <Paper corpusId="255981073" paperTitle="(Ye et al._1, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

In yeast systems, CRISPR/Cas9 has been successfully applied to commercial strains to optimize recombinant protein production and metabolic performance. For wine yeasts specifically, this technology has created engineered strains with reduced urea production, higher osmotic tolerance, and improved aromatic complexity. <Paper corpusId="258818373" paperTitle="(Fazio et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="25325511" paperTitle="(Vigentini et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> These applications demonstrate CRISPR's versatility in addressing industry-specific challenges while improving protein expression characteristics.

The development of advanced CRISPR/Cas9 systems with self-splicing sgRNAs or multifunctional gRNAs has simplified repeated genomic edits that previously required multiple rounds of screening processes. This simplification has significantly streamlined the engineering of expression systems across multiple microbial hosts. <Paper corpusId="263721852" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> Dynamic promoter expression systems (DPESs) enabled by CRISPR technology have achieved precise up- and down-regulation of heterologous metabolic pathways not only in yeast but also in other microbial systems like Bacillus subtilis and Escherichia coli, enhancing protein production through coordinated gene expression. <Paper corpusId="263721852" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

Beyond yeast and E. coli, CRISPR/Cas9 has expanded the toolkit for recombinant protein expression in filamentous fungi, particularly in the Aspergillus genus, which is widely used for biosynthesis of natural and recombinant bioproducts. <Paper corpusId="263721852" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> The clear genetic backgrounds of these microbial hosts, combined with the precision of CRISPR/Cas9 technology, make it significantly easier to optimize recombinant protein production for industrial applications. <Paper corpusId="264071809" paperTitle="(Yang et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

These applications of CRISPR in recombinant protein expression systems demonstrate how advanced genetic engineering tools have progressed beyond simple gene modifications to enable complex, multi-gene optimizations that can be precisely tuned for specific production requirements. The integration of expression systems directly into host chromosomes, coupled with the development of variant libraries and dynamic expression control, has significantly enhanced both the predictability and efficiency of recombinant protein production in industrial microbial hosts.

snippets: An extensive repertoire of molecular tools is available for genetic analysis in laboratory strains of S. cerevisiae. Although this has widely contributed to the interpretation of gene functionality within haploid laboratory isolates, the genetics of metabolism in commercially-relevant polyploid yeast strains is still poorly understood. Genetic engineering in industrial yeasts is undergoing major changes due to Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) and CRISPR-associated protein (Cas) engineering approaches. Here we apply the CRISPR/Cas9 system to two commercial "starter" strains of S. cerevisiae (EC1118, AWRI796), eliminating the CAN1 arginine permease pathway to generate strains with reduced urea production (18.5 and 35.5% for EC1118 and AWRI796, respectively). In a wine-model environment based on two grape musts obtained from Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon cultivars, both S. cerevisiae starter strains and CAN1 mutants completed the must fermentation in 8–12 days. However, recombinant strains carrying the can1 mutation failed to produce urea, suggesting that the genetic modification successfully impaired the arginine metabolism. In conclusion, the reduction of urea production in a wine-model environment confirms that the CRISPR/Cas9 system has been successfully established in S. cerevisiae wine yeasts.

sections.title: Other Advanced Genetic Tools Beyond CRISPR/Cas9
sections.tldr: While CRISPR/Cas9 has revolutionized genome editing, several alternative technologies offer complementary capabilities for genetic engineering in microbial systems. These include ZFNs, TALENs, MAGE, YOGE, and other specialized tools that enable diverse manipulation strategies from site-specific modifications to genome-wide engineering. (7 sources)
sections.text:
Beyond CRISPR/Cas9, several advanced genetic engineering tools have significantly contributed to improving recombinant protein expression in microbial systems:

* **Zinc Finger Nucleases (ZFNs)**: These engineered proteins combine a zinc finger DNA-binding domain with the FokI nuclease domain to create targeted double-strand breaks in DNA. ZFNs can modify specific genes involved in protein biogenesis either temporarily or permanently. <Paper corpusId="236320664" paperTitle="(Abaandou et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

* **Transcription Activator-Like Effector Nucleases (TALENs)**: Similar to ZFNs, TALENs use protein-DNA interactions for targeting and the FokI enzyme to introduce DNA breaks. Although more precise than ZFNs, constructing the specific DNA binding proteins remains labor-intensive. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="743414" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>

* **Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering (MAGE)**: This technology enables rapid and continuous generation of genetic diversity through iterative cycles of targeted genome modifications. MAGE has been successfully applied to optimize the MEP pathway in E. coli for lycopene production and can generate vast numbers of combinatorial genomic variants. <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="52962258" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

* **Yeast Oligo-Mediated Genome Engineering (YOGE)**: Adapted for S. cerevisiae from the bacterial recombineering approach, YOGE enables high-frequency oligonucleotide-directed genome modification. Through optimization of transformation protocols and oligonucleotide designs, YOGE can achieve modification frequencies that require screening of only dozens of cells rather than thousands. <Paper corpusId="5282362" paperTitle="(Kavscek et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="7142289" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al._1, 2013)" isShortName></Paper>

* **Trackable Multiplex Recombineering (TRMR)**: This approach enables parallel modification and tracking of thousands of genes in a single population by using synthetic DNA cassettes. <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

* **Recombination-Assisted Genome Engineering (RAGE)**: RAGE facilitates large-scale genome modification through iterative cycles of homologous recombination, allowing researchers to build and diversify biosynthetic pathways. <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

* **CRISPR-Enabled Trackable Genome Engineering (CREATE)**: Combining CRISPR targeting with oligonucleotide-mediated allelic replacement, CREATE enables rapid and efficient creation of mutant libraries with trackable genetic barcodes. <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

* **CRISPR/Cas9-facilitated Homologous recombination At Multiple Genomic loci for continuous Evolution (CHAnGE)**: This system rapidly evolves yeast strains on a genome-wide scale to improve tolerance to growth inhibitors by enabling simultaneous modification of multiple genetic loci. <Paper corpusId="203437687" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

Many of these technologies can be applied in complementary ways with CRISPR systems. For example, MAGE is most effective when combined with high-throughput screening systems that enable selection of variants with desired traits, particularly for optimizing metabolic pathways for compounds like β-carotene in both E. coli and S. cerevisiae. <Paper corpusId="52962258" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>

Unlike CRISPR/Cas9, which relies on RNA-DNA recognition, tools like ZFNs and TALENs use protein-DNA interactions to target specific genomic loci. This fundamental difference results in varied capabilities: while CRISPR offers easier programming through guide RNA changes, these alternative systems may offer advantages in certain contexts despite being more labor-intensive to design. <Paper corpusId="238533448" paperTitle="(Shan et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

The development of these diverse genetic engineering tools has created a comprehensive toolkit that enables researchers to select the most appropriate technology based on their specific needs for improving recombinant protein expression in microbial systems. <Paper corpusId="5282362" paperTitle="(Kavscek et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>
